raw_text: Also, a wide-coverage statistical parser which produces syntactic dependency structures for English is available for CCG (Clark et al, 2002)
clean_text: Also, a wide-coverage statistical parser which produces syntactic dependency structures for English is available for CCG (Clark et al, 2002).

citing_paper_authors: Wenduan, Xu | Stephen, Clark | Yue, Zhang
raw_text: The early dependency model of Clark et al (2002), in which model features were define dover only dependency structures, was partly motivated by these theoretical observations. More generally, dependency models are desirable for a number of reasons
clean_text: The early dependency model of Clark et al (2002), in which model features were defined over only dependency structures, was partly motivated by these theoretical observations.

raw_text: Excluding Johnson (2002)? s pattern-matching algorithm, most recent work on finding head? dependencies with statistical parser has used statistical versions of deep grammar formalisms, such as CCG (Clark et al, 2002) or LFG (Riezler et al, 2002)
clean_text: Excluding Johnson (2002)'s pattern-matching algorithm, most recent work on finding head-dependencies with statistical parser has used statistical versions of deep grammar formalisms, such as CCG (Clark et al, 2002) or LFG (Riezler et al, 2002).

raw_text: This paper assumes a basic understanding of CCG; see Steedman (2000) for an introduction, and Clark et al (2002) and Hockenmaier (2003a) for an introduction to statistical parsing with CCG
clean_text: This paper assumes a basic understanding of CCG; see Steedman (2000) for an introduction, and Clark et al (2002) and Hockenmaier (2003a) for an introduction to statistical parsing with CCG.

raw_text: However, the introduction of extra derivations increases the complexity of the modelling and parsing problem. Clark et al (2002) handle the additional derivations by modelling the derived structure, in their case dependency structures
clean_text: Clark et al (2002) handle the additional derivations by modelling the derived structure, in their case dependency structures.

raw_text: This extends the approach of Clark et al (2002) who modelled the dependency structures directly, not using any information from the derivations
clean_text: This extends the approach of Clark et al (2002) who modelled the dependency structures directly, not using any information from the derivations.

raw_text: In contrast to the dependency model, the normal-form model simply defines a distribution over normal form derivations. The dependency structures considered in this pa per are described in detail in Clark et al (2002) and Clark and Curran (2003)
clean_text: The dependency structures considered in this paper are described in detail in Clark et al (2002) and Clark and Curran (2003).

raw_text: Following Clark et al (2002), evaluation is by precision and recall over dependencies
clean_text: Following Clark et al (2002), evaluation is by precision and recall over dependencies.

clean_text: Following Clark et al (2002), we augment CCG lexical categories with head and dependency information.

raw_text: This paper argues that probabilistic parsers should therefore model the dependencies in the predicate-argument structure, as in the model of Clark et al (2002), and defines a generative model for CCG derivations that captures these dependencies ,including bounded and unbounded long-range dependencies
clean_text: This paper argues that probabilistic parsers should therefore model the dependencies in the predicate-argument structure, as in the model of Clark et al (2002), and defines a generative model for CCG derivations that captures these dependencies, including bounded and unbounded long-range dependencies.

raw_text: The conditional model used by the CCG parser of Clark et al (2002) also captures dependencies in the predicate-argument structure; however, their model is inconsistent
clean_text: The conditional model used by the CCG parser of Clark et al (2002) also captures dependencies in the predicate-argument structure; however, their model is inconsistent.

raw_text: Like Clark et al (2002), we define predicate argument structure for CCG in terms of the dependencies that hold between words with lexical functor categories and their arguments
clean_text: Like Clark et al (2002), we define predicate argument structure for CCG in terms of the dependencies that hold between words with lexical functor categories and their arguments.
